sourceDesc.bibl: The Egyptian Gazette Wednesday, January 16, 1907 6 pages

cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oretava" will leave Suez about January 28
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about Februray 8.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said January 28
R.M.S. “Ortona" will leave Port Said February 12

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare lack if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or statement of 20% if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May-15th September.
Agents: Cairo, Thomas Cook & Son Ltd. Alexandria: R.J. Moss & Co.
For all information apply to Wm. Stapledon & Bone, Port Said & Port Tewfix (Suez), 31-12-4

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, will leave Suez about January 17, 1907.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, will leave Port Said about January 26th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG, weekly from Antwerp: every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBURG. Goods forwared at through from all German railway stations on direct. and vice-versa, admitting goods from all chief German Railway Stations on direct. Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, and SYRIA etc. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton etc. from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing powers.
Steamers AT ALEXANDRIA.
Expect S.S. Tinos Jan 16 from Antwerp bound for Rotterdam & Hamburg
Expect S.S. Paros Jan 20 from Antwerp--Jan. 27 S.S. Enos from Hamburg
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. for a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Tabor now on the berth, will sail on or about Thursday, 17th January to be followed by S.S. Seti.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: The Steamers of this line leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
SALOON FARE £12.
S.S. Tenasserim 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about 12th January for Liverpool.
S.S. Arracas 6000 Tons will leave ALEXANDRIA about 12th January for Liverpool.
S.S. Amarapoora 6600 Tons will leave ALEXANDRIA about 12th January for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL in 13 days
The saloon accomodation is amidships and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light, and have all the latest improvements.
For further information apply to the Company's Agents.
WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: EXPRESS NILE STEAMER Co.
div.p: Cairo-Luxor Tourist Service -- Luxor-Assouan Express Service.
Departures from Cairo Dec. 29; Jan. 12, 26; Feb 9, 23; March 13,
Quick Freight Service ALEXANDRIA-CAIRO.
89662 For Bookings and Particulars apply: CAIRO OFFICES, 19, CHAREH-EL MADABEGH.

div.head: Asia Minor Steamship Co., Ltd.
div.p: Regular sailings to Cyprus and Coast of Syria, Steamer leaves Alexandria every alternate Monday afternoon for Limassol, Larnace, Femagusta, via Port Said. First Class Single Fare, Alex. or P. Said to Cyprus £2 Sailings Hable to alteration owing to Quarantine etc.
For further particulars apply: Manager, 3 St. Mark's Street, Alexandria

div.head: WHITE STAR LINE.
div.p: NEW YORK AND BOSTON MEDITERRANEAN SERVICE.

Regular Sailings between Alexandria , Naples, and Boston or New York, U.S.A. By the large modern twin screw steamers CEDRIC, 21,000 tons- CELTIC, 21,000 tons- REPUBLIC, 15,400 tons- CANOPIC, 13,000 tons.

Regular Service between Italy and United States throughout the year. Excellent accommodation for all classes of passengers. For plans of steamers, rates of passengers between the various ports, and full particulars, apply to THOS, COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., Cairo, Alexandria, Luxor and Assouan; John Ross & Co., Alexandria; White Star Line, Via Roma, Gena, and 21, Piazza della Borsa, Naples.

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.
NILE STEAMER SERVICES
TOURIST SERVICE: The large and splendidly appointed S.S. RAMESES THE GREAT will leave Cairo on Tuesday, January 22nd for Luxor, Assuan, and Philae.
EXPRESS SERVICE: Steamers leave Cairo every Monday and Friday for Luxor, Assuan, and Philae, 19 days on the Nile for 22.
WEEKLY SERVICE TO HALFA, KHARTOUM AND THE SOUDAN.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: British India S. N. Company, Limited.
div.p: Fortnightly Service in connection with the Co's Indian Mail Lines.-- Calling at ADEN, COLOMBO, MADRAS, and CALCUTTA Out, and MARSEILLES (GENOA and PLYMOUTH optional) Home. Sailings from Suez.
OUTWARD.—QUEEN ELEANOR ... Jan. 9 | HOMEWARD.—S.S. Avora ... Jan. 16
EAST AFRICAN LINE OF STEAMERS.
Calling at Aden, Mombasa, Zanzibar and Beira. Monthly service.
S.S. Baluchristan will sail from Suez on about the 27th January.

The S.S. Egyptian now loading for Liverpool will sail in a few days to be followed by S.S. Britannia and Belgravian.

div.head: Russian Stream Navigation & Commercial Company.
div.p: Postal Service Accelerated from the 1st June 1906
between Alexandria, Piraeus, Constantinople, and Odessa by the following recenlty built and perfectly equipped vessels:
Arrivals at Alexandria on Friday mornings.
Departures from Alexandria on Tuesdays at 3 p.m.. Circular route between Alexandria, Port Said, the Syrian ports, Chio, Smyrna, Salonica, Mount Athos, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
Arrivals at Alexandria every other Saturday early in the morning.
Departures from Alexandria same day in afternoon at 4 p.m.
Crimean or Bessarabian table wines free.

div.head: Cunard Line
div.p: New twin-screw S.S. CARONI 20,000 tons, sailing from Alexandria on 20th January for Fiume, Naples, and New York.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. connecting with the Train de Luxe, Trieste Vienna Ostende. Passengers reach London Friday 4:50 p.m.
Intermediate Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 10 a.m.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line: Steamer leaves Alexandria about 7, 15, 21, 29 January (4 p.m.)
Far East Lines: Departures from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama and Kobé, 3 Feb., 6 March, 3 April, 4 May.
To Suez, Aden and Bombay accelerated service about 7, 22 Jan. ; 7,22 Feb, 7, 23 March ; 8, 23 April ; 8 May
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about 18 Jan., 18 Feb., 18 March, 18 April, 18 May, 18
For information apply to the Agents, Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, and Khartum.
Special rates for Egyptian officials, members of Army of Occupation and their families.

div.head: THE PAPAYANNI LINE (The Ellerman Lines, Ltd.)
div.p: Frequent Sailings from ALEXANDRIA to LIVERPOOL, also Regular Services from LIVERPOOL to ALEXANDRIA and to ALGERIA, MALTA, LEVANT, BLACK SEA, and other Mediterranean Ports.
Excellent Passenger Accommodation. Stewardess carried. Liberal table and Moderate Fares for single and return tickets.
The S.S. CITY OF ETHOS will sail for Liverpool in a few days and will be followed by the S.S. ALEXANDRIA
CARGO taken by special agreement only. Through Freights quoted for the UNITED STATES and INLAND TOWNS in GREAT BRITAIN.
For passage or freight apply to the Agents, BARKER & Co., Alexandria. 17-4-907

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM MAIL SERVICE.--WINTER TIME-TABLES 1906-1907.
‡Sleeping and Dining Cars.
Note.—Express teamers carry first-class passengers only. Slow steamers carry second and third class passengers who would have to leave Cairo on Tuesdays and Saturdays. 14-6-907

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - MOTOR BUS MEETS ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. MANAGER REINSPERCES

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Tooth Powder
div.p: Clean, White Teeth mean sound Teeth fit for their work, the condition they are kept in by the use of
Calvert's Carbolic Tooth Powder
It is made for cleaning the Teeth, and does it, too, pleasantly, thoroughly, and gently without scratching or injuring the enamel. That is why it is in such constant demand all over the world.
Sold by local Chemists and Stores.
F.C. Calvert & Co., Manchester, Eng.

div.head: Tyrol.
div.p: (Weissenstein Castle 103 feet). First-class. Private Hotel, near Windisch-Matrei station, Lienz. ( Easily reached from Trieste or Venice. ) Bracing air. Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing. Photos and Prospectuses at "Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo. 29218-30A-4-907

div.head: Howie's Butter
div.p: Residents returning from Europe and who have no hitherto used Howie's Butter
should not fail to give it a trial, before making their winter arrangements.
Address:–-Shubra Road, Cairo.

div.head: British Commercial Travellers
div.p: Visiting Cairo should arrange with "The Commercial Bureau"
Sharia Madahegh for introduction to Firms.

div.head: The Best Guide Book For the Nile.

Dedicated by Permission to the Earl of Cromer
C.C.S. & c.
Egypt, Its Pyramids & Progress
By John Ward, F.S.A.
With an Introduction by the Rev. Professor, SAYCE, D.D. L.L.D. & c. Foolscap to 308 pp. Illustrations Maps and Plans 7s. 6d. Net.
F. Diemer and other Booksellers.
Cairo.
Eyre & Spottiswoode, Publishers, London, E.C.

Customs-Clearing & Forwarding

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p:
Built In 1904. Modern House. Splendid situation. Eectric Light
Lift, Pension P.T. 50. Arrangements for families.
Rooms and Breakfast P.T. 25.— Meals a la Cart

div.head: Brass Door Plates
div.p: With Mahogany Block, Wall on Gate, J. Margosches, Hulac Road, Cairo

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: NEW VICTORIA HOTEL,
div.p: Open all the year round.
San Stefano, Near Alexandria, Halt No. 2.

Specially built in 1904 for a class Hotel with every modern comfort. Magnificent Dining room, Saloons, Smoking room, largo Verandahs and Garden. Electric light. MODERATE CHARGES. Express Motor Cars meet trains from Cairo at Sidi Gabor and Alexandria Stations. The management have also arranged for the Motor Cars to meet all steamers. Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation. C. F. RAISIG. Manager.
RESTAURANT AND BAR OPEN TO NON-RESIDENTS.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Khartoum

Entirely re-built, enlarged and refurnished in 1906; replete with all modern European comforts.
Electric light, steam laundry, lawn-tennis, stabling, boating, own farm and dairy products, Cosmpolotian cuisine, european service

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

The weather has now settled down to wintry conditions. Yesterday was again dull and cheerless. During the night a light gale sprangip from the S.W., and continues till this morning, the wind being intensley cold. The barometer is steady. Today promises to be dull and cold, and some rain may fall.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.

div.head: THE HELLENIC CASE
div.p: M. Athos Romanos, the well-known Greek politician and ex-Minister for Foreign Affairs in the previous Theotokis Cabinet, has just published a well-written pamphlet on the persecution of his countrymen by the Bulgarians. As the Greeks are being continually censured for their conduct to the Bulgarians in Macedonia, it is only fair that it should be realised that there is another side of the question.

M. Romanos has wisely accompanied his statements with photographs showing the havoc wrought by the Bulgarians in the Greek Club and the Greek School at Philippopolis, the latter founded by M. Maraslis, of Odense, the well-known Greek philanthropist and patriot, and the almost complete destruction of the Hellenic quarter of Anchialos, on the Black Sen. It is noticeable, as one of these photographs demonstrates, that the conflagration, which destroyed nine hundred Greek houses and shops, stopped, as if by miracle, before the walls of the Bulgarian Church - miracle worthy of the Middle Ages, which was doubtless intended to point the moral that walvation of | life and property is to be found by those who follow the Bulgarian Exarch rather than by the adherents of the Ecumenical Patriarch. The Bulgarians say that the fault lay with the Greeks, who provoked reprisals by their resistance. It would have been greatly to the discredit of the latter if they had not done so. Anchialos contained six thousand Greeks, and when they saw one of their compatriots fall, pierced by a Bulgarian bullet, they naturally fired on his murderers. Not having many weapons they could not beat off the Bulgarian bands, and the fire ere long rendered further resistance impossible,

M. Romanos complains bitterly that the Bulgarian Government has not restored to his fellow-countrymen their churches and schools. The Bulgarian lion, he wys waves over the Marasli school at Philippopolis, which has been proclaimed State property, and no less than sixty-six Greek schools, formerly attended by eight thousand pupils, have been closed by the application of a clause in the Bulgarian Education Act of 1891 which has hitherto been a dead letter. M. Romanos points out that this action constitutes an infringement of the religious liberty guaranteed to the Greeks of Bulgaria by the Berlin Treaty and by the Organic Statute of Eastern Rumelia (now South Bulgaria). He might have added, that complete religious toleration exists in Greece, whether the creed concerned be that of the Roman Catholics of the Cyclades and the Ionian Islands or that of the few Mussulmans who have remained in Thessaly since its retrocession to Greece in 1898. The very first Article of the Greek Constitution, while forbidding proselytism, guarantees complete religious liberty, and this is not a mere rhetorical flourish of the Parliamentary draughtsman, but fact The State subsidies the Turkish muftis of Thessaly, and Roman Catholics and Jews have their own religious instruction in the public elementary schools.

It is no doubt, unfortunate that the Eastern Christians should hate each other so cordially, but they have always done so, and in that res peet they differ only in degree from the more civilised Western Christians Europe, however, is entitled to know that the fault is not all on one side and that all Bulgarians are not angels and all Greeks are not the opposite. Finlay, himself • Philhellene, could laugh during the War of Independence at the extravagances of Philhellenism. But people are now in danger of going to the opposite extreme that of thinking that the Greeks can do nothing right because they have, like even the youngest of us, made some mistakes.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Pilgrimage
The Holy Carpet and it's escort arrived at Moons on the 8th inst., after purging a quarantine of 48 hours on Abou Sand Island
The Brindley Mail.
The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will arrive at Alexandria at 3 o'clock. and will be distributed at the G.P.O. at 4:30
Repression of Slave Trade
During last month the Slave Trade Repression Department released from slavery 80 persons, viz. 7 Sundanese men and 99 women, and one Abyssinian.
Alhambra Theatre

The Lauri and Serafini variety troupe will appear tonight at this theatre, which they have blessed from M. Conegliano The first marked tall of the season will be bed at this theatre on Saturday at midnight.
Street “Up".

M. Nicolas D. Toccor, the well known cities rent merchant, writes to complain of the inconvenience be experiences owing to the upheaval of the roadway in front of his shop in the Place des Consoles for gas works.
Asphalting Pavements.

The tender of the Val de Travers Asphalte Paving Company for asphalting the foot pavement at Alexandria for three years has been scooped by the Municipality. The company undertake to do the work at P.T. 19 the square metre
Files In Egypt

The "Washington Star" says : William Jennings Bryan was talking to Terre Haute about his recent world tour. "A winter in Egypt," he said, "is a superb thing. all but the flies. The flies in Egypt are as bad as the Central American mosquitoes."
Tourist Steamer

The steam yacht Meteor, of the Hamburg America Line, arrived at Alexandria this morning with 85 passengers, who proceeded to Cairo, where they will be lodged at the Continental Hotel. The Meteor leaves again on Sanday for the Syrian coast.
Violators Attacked.

M. Bouboolis, oor distinguished Hellenie goont, accompanied by M. and Mme Salvage. went for a motor drive to Pompey's Pillar yesterday. day. Another unpleasant incident occurred when they neared Kom el Shoogafs, the party being pelted with stones by some Arab ngameffios. Portoestely bone was a bit. The Arabe were taken in obarge.
The Greek Theatre

M. Vocobos gave an excellent lecture on the "Greek Theatre" at the New Khedivial Hotel on Saturday night. The Hellenio Cor tal-General presided. The gist of the lecture was that the theatre is bad, and still has, powerful political influence in Greece. In the course of bis remarks be referred to that barone Dame Mourous, who fought in the httle of Dragaobin in Moldavir, for Hellenie Independence.
A Now Contemporary

"Le Monde Hellénique," new French contemporary published at Athens has been sent to us. It contains much that is interesting of Near Eastern news, and inter alia, segments the establishment of Hellenie Cdanslate at Cairo, to relieve the Hellenic Diplomatic Agent. Macedonian aftaire, of course, engross the jaardal's attention, and enhance its value and record of the political situation in the Balkans. The proprietor and editor is M. Spyridon G. Pappas
Charity Foto

An obarity fee will be bold next Sunday afternoon in the "salle des fêtes" of the Khadi. vial Hotel, kindly lent for the occasion by the Management, in sid of the fonts of the "Comite des Jeunes Boonomes," presided by Moe Girard, wite of the French Consul-General Stores of the entertainment, which is he'd appeally, will include dancing for the children, to start at 8 30 pm., the drawing of a lottery, afternoon tea, eto. The committee trust that their efforts will meet, as heretofore, with the generous support of the public, and that w parents and children will attend in large bombers.

div.head: BIG HAUL OF HASHISH,
div.p: £5,000 WORTH SEIZED.
ENGLISH RESIDENTS INTREPIDITY

Very important seizures of hashish were made at Ramleh on Monday and yesterday, which illustrate in a remarkable manner how adept the servants of some of the most respectable fans in Berkeley are in running bashish. The house of Mr. HC. Parkinson, the general manager of the Khedivial Mail Steamship Company, is right on the lift at Berkeley, and is protected from the inroads of the seas by an almost perpendicular sea wall. Access to the house from the beach is obtained by some steps on the wall. The Coastguard Administration's patrol cannot get to the coast at this point as the approaches to the East and West are cloned by two walls to the end of the cliff.

Early on Monday morning, at about 1 o'clock, Mr. Parkinson was aroused from his slumbers by peculiar thudding noise. He went round the house and was surprised to find light in his kitchen. He entered and found his suffrage engaged in making tea. The suffrage said that it was bad to be out, and, feeling cold, thought he would make some tea. This explanation did not, however, not count for the strange noise, so Mr. Parkinson ordered the man to go out and see if anybody was moving about in the er d'osure. The man went off and came back soon afterwards declaring that he could not find a soul outside, and that all was quiet.

Mr. Parkinson then went to bed again, but soon afterwards he again heard the mysterious thud, thud, thud, jost outside his house. Rounded with people walking in the yard of his horse dragging huge weights with them, and they distinctly noted the footfalls. He determined to probe the mystery to its depths and, arming himself with a loaded revolver, he went himself to ascertain the truth. It was pitch dark night, and nothing could be distinguished. Batas be was moving round and nearly stumbled over a big sack. He at once goers what game was being played and recognised that hasbieb was being landed. He went to his telephone and rang the Coast guard station at Ramelb, which is only about five hundred metres off. Help was at once sent and eighteen sacks of bashish were found round about the enclosure. One of the sacks was brought to light hidden in the room of Mr. Parkinson's suffragette.

The importance of this seizure may be recognised when it is known that the selling price of such an amount of hashish would be between L.E. 4,500 and L.E. 5,000, for the sacks contained twelve hundred kilo over a ton's weight

The suffrage was handed over by Mr. Parkinson to the Coast Guard, who took him into custody. Evidently the sacks of hashish had been floated in from a boat lying in the offing, as it is impossible to eftaota landing there except on moonlight night. The smugglers must have been very somerous as it would require at least ten men to marry off seob a large haal. When Mr. Parkinson was ringing up the telephone to the Coast Guard he heard the sound of the whole carriage driving rapidly away. This no doubt contained some of the smugglers.

Yesterday, when the coast guard were taking the suffrage to the Customs Administration Commission in order to be brought to trial, he said that he had some news to tell them, and he volunteered the information that if they I would look in the stable of the house adjoining Mr. Parkinson's, which is inhabited by Mr. Borohgrevink, the Procureur General of the Mixed Tribunals, they would find another tres tre trove of ashish. Subsequently, on a search being made, tourteen sacks were found hidden under the tibia in Mri. Borchgrevink's stable. His native coachman, who has been Gitteen years in bis service, is about to be taken into custody. Both be and Mr. Parkinson's suffrage were most respectable servants. The latter was in the service of Major Mackenzie Pendrell for some time. Evidently the servants in houses by the sea at Ramleh are corrupted by the smugglers, who are quite able to offer Snormons bribes of hundreds of pounds for 9-operation.

Mr. Parkinson and his next-door neighbour, Mr. C.A.H. Alderson, have now given the Coast Guard Administration permission to station a guard within their enclosures, as this part of the coast is evidently convenient pace for running hashish I To show how carefully laid were the sung Iglars plans on this occasion, we must mention that Mr. Parkinson on Sunday night did not notice his fax terrier and only saw it again at about 7 o'clock next morning, when it oame home collarless and lame. It had been removed the day before and tied up some way off. flag the dog been in the bonae, it would have at once given the salary,

Two hours after the discovery of the hashish "the Coastguards in the Eastern Harbour were arrested . suspicious looking native craft, which | welt strongly of hs bish and bad on board an empty portmanteau, which also had the same odont. It bore a Greek label. The boat and crew were taken into custody and the latter are to be brought before the Custom Commission.

It is understood that the bashish found at Bulkeley was brought over from Greece in sobooner, which was met off Aboukir by vative boat There is no doubt that this great se zute of £5,000 worth of ba hsh is entirely due to the plook of Mr. Parkinson, who ventured out alone at a time when there must have been at least ten smugglers in the bus compound, all of them desperate at the prospect of losing such a valuable cargo.

div.head: THE OASES
div.p: GOVERNMENT MEASURES

The Egyptian Government has decided to shortly appoint Mr. R. & Patterror, of the Inspectorate of the Ministry of Finance, Inspector of the four one of Khraab. Dakhleb, Babariah, and Paratra. This appointment of Mr. Patterson will be for two years and special powers will appear to that official.

The Ministry of Finance has decided to carry out a thorough survey of all the land Down under cultivation or which will be brought under cultivation in the near future in these four onres, which have never been surveyed before except geologically. In the Oases of Khargeh band Dakhleh the basis of taxation in water instead of land, elsewhere in Egypt. This survey will be undertaken with a view to eventually changing the basis o as to bring the principle of taxation prevailing in there ones in harmony with that in vogue throughout the rest of Egypt.
Mr. Buckley, of the Irrigation Department, who is at present employed at the Ghizeh Pumping Station, will leave shortly for Kharge to enquire into questions connected with the water supply.

div.head: THE RITZ HOTELS
div.p: HOTEL FOR ALEXANDRIA.

The Ritz Hotels (Egypt). Limited, bas decided to build a palatial botel at Alexandria, As excellent site has already been proposed, the company having bought the beautiful mansion of Baron Pélix de Menace for £67,000, The Baron's house and garden are situated in the most fashionable residential quarter of Alexandria, with frontage on Rosetta street. The hotel which the Ritz Hotels intend to build is to be fitted with all the latest improvements and will in every respect vie with the best establishments of a similar kind in Egypt.
THE STATE BANK

At the fortnightly meeting of the board of directors of the National Book of Egypt to morrow the board will consider the comments and criticisms of the Bayptian Government on the proposals of the National Bank with respect to the State Bank subeme Prom what we bear there is every chance of tbe scheme being carried through without any serious hitch.
KENEH-ASSOUAN RAILWAY.

The Egyptian Railway Administration is making great improvements on the Keneb Assouan lino. A considerable outlay on this section of the Upper Egypt line is fully justified, as the traffic berea Luxor sod Asso Can be recently greatly increased. lo fact, owing to this somewhat unexpected development of the passenger trofas, taken in connection with the heavy goods traffic and the large quantity of material transported for the works in progress on the line, the resources of the railway have been severely strained. The bomber of passengers booked at Ampuan alone is about double the number dealt with at Port Said. To meet the development of the traffic now can have been pet on between Luxor and Arouse and a regular dining car is also to be put on. So far as the road is concerned, great improvements are to be made.
A BANKRUPT PATRIARCHATE.

Dar Constantinople Correspondent reporter that aboription has been opened there to meet deficit of LT. 4.000 in the funds of the Armenian Gregorian Patriarobate. Daring the first two days of its opening LT. 600 ware received. An appeal to the Armenian Church in Egypt is to be made through the Vicar General of the Patriarchate
REVOLUTIONARY CAIRO:

We have been favoured by the Ottoman Constitutional League, lately founded at Cairo, with copies of its statuten, which are printed in French, Tarkish, Arabie, and Armenian. Its programme consists of ten articles, defining its objects, which a . to re establish, by all means legitimate, constitutional government in Turkey, with a responsible Ministry. All Ottoman subjects, irrespective of race and creed, may form part of the league, which will have its headquarters for the time being at Cairo, will appoint' sab committees, and direct their plan of action. The pamphlet winds up with an appeal to patriotism in behalf of the liberation of millions of unfortunates.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS,
The Moss liner Mones arrived in Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The S.S. British Pride, with passengers and general cargo from Alexandria, via Malta, arrived at Manchester on the 13th inst.

div.head: WORKMEN'S HOUSES.
div.p: MUNICIPALITY'S REPLY TO COMMISSION

As our readers are aware, a letter which was something of the nature of an ultimatum, as addressed by the Popular Houses Commission to the Alexandria Municipality on the 11th inst, calling for some statement as to the progress of the scheme, placed before the authorities, failing which the Commission threatened to resign in a body.

An official answer is now for booming ln a letter dated the 14th ist to Cavaliere Ronel, president of the com minion, the Administrator of the Municipality, Mr. W. P. Chata way, acknowledges receipt of the former's letter, which he promises to com to unioa'e to the Delegation, and adds that, from information received, be is able to state that the Government has completed its study of the proposal relative to the land necessary for the work men's dwellings, and that definite reply will be given in a few days.
THE RECENT EARTHQUAKE

The earthquake which wrought aneh awful buvoo in the West Indies and obliterated Kingston on Monday last, .wms fault in Egypt on the day. Some people declare that they experienced tremulous sensation as of an earthquake. The fact that on Monday evening the election wires at Ramleh, Cairo, and Jealous tapped and the light went out is presumed to have some connection with the earthquake.
ZAGAZIG STREET LIGHTING.

A difference has arisen between the Ministry of Public Works and of the Interior, on the one side, and the Ligasig Municipality on the other. It appears that on June 11, 1906, the Municipality beld meeting to discuss the question of lighting the streets of the towa with gas or electricity, and finally appointed committee of four of its members, including the sab moudir, to visit several towns and study the merits and demerits of the various systems. After a study of their comparative merite the committee drew up a report in favour of the adoption of electric lighting. The Ministry of Public Works had other views. Mr. Perry. Under Secretary of State for Towns and Buildings, in note addressed to Sir W. Garstin, Recommended the adoption of the Mansfield gas system. The Municipality, however, read the report sud voted for eleo tricity, and there the matter resta · In our opinion, the Zaganigians (or should - write Zgarie Pea) might be left to choose for themselves aplex their proposal is likely to involve them in very high expenditure. After all, if are to love municipalities in the provincial towns they should not be, a to speak, spoon ted by the central authorities, uples invalided by their financial) excesses.
KHARTOUM'S STREETS.

It is esmaestly hoped that the Government will increase the money devoted to the main tenets of the Khartoum streets. The increase in the traffic, bob wheeled and otherwise, has been enormous of late and consequently the strain on the roads, particularly the most frequented thoroughfare has been such a to leave them in a very bad condition unless they are properly looked after.

We are aware of the financial difficulties which stand in the way of lavish expenditure on the roads; and until the water works are an accomplished fact, it will not be easy to keep the roads in good condition. Besides, the Government has hundreds of projects for the development of the country for snobs of which large amounts of money are urgently required. But in voicing the public opinion on this matter we hope that some means may be found to give the Capital of the Badan better streets so as to keep pace with the remarkable development of the town. ("Sudan Times")
GHEZIREH PALACE.

By kind permission of Lieut. Col. B. A. Herbert, M. V. O, and others, the band of the 6th (Inniskilling) Dragoons will play a programme of music during dinner and dance setter at the Ghezireh Palace Hotel on Thursday evening. commencing at 8 o'clock.

1 Characteristic Piece The Coon's Patrol - Letter
2 Overture-La Lyre d'Or-Herman
3 Walta-Nachtschwaermer-Fels
4 Selection - The Little Cherub Caryll

div.head: CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.
div.p: Several excellent plots of this estate are offered, at reasonable rates. Apply to Mr. C. Aquilina, Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON, M.P.
div.p: VISIT TO ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM

Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P. paid visit to the Alexandria Museum yesterday. He was very pleased with the progress that the Museum is making and expressed his satisfaction to Professor Breccia, the curator of the Museum. H. displayed keen interest in many of the srebæological tronenres which be noticed. Professor Brescis personally sendast od Mr. Robertson over the building and we thanked that gentleman for his attention.
Mr. Robertson left Alexandria today for Cairo by the midday express.

"Al Watan," the Coptie organ, in ite in retorting portrait gallery of the friends and supporters of Mustapha Pasha Komel, devotes ito ninth character sketob to Mr. Robertson, whom it deals with as follow -

We now deal with Mr. John Robertson, M.P. He has clothed himself in the cast offs of M. Delancey, merely sewing on Yew Union Jacks. Consequently be has become the friend of our enthusiasts and their saviour from the laws of the Lion in Occupation. Had he thought fit to visit the Best Indies instead of hoisting his flag on the banks of the Nile he would have only foord semis. Por the(Moslem) Nationalista of lodia have decided (vide their recent manifesto) that Begland is their friend and their protector and that their daty is to give proote of their loyalty. But our patriotard has not yet capitulated.

We remarked that Robertson is the friend of certain enthusiasts; be has left for the provinces by express invitation of some of our "bona bourgeois.Bat does the publio remember the renowned Dolo Polo and his protestations of friendship, the immense banqueta offered him, and all the money squandered on bis visit to Bcrypt 1 None the lease be sold the country to Bagland, he forgot us all, and has apparently also forgotten his own past policy. We may add that he was always in pain to help himself to all that came his way. One day we shall doubtless bay a third De lonoke who will give petition of this someday German Delono-who knows There is a good opening for him and his likes as long as there exist with lens individual with impossible dreams and the fixed idea that Tonal departs from M. P. os sway the politician of a great nation. Yes, German Delonole and Teatos Robertson are possible. Amid the clinking of glasses, flanked by appetising dishes, fired with the glowing costao that good cheer has kindled, chimerio visions will defile before our patriots' eyes : the armies of the Sultan of Germany swelled by the hosts of the great Padishah advancing to expel the English from Egypt. The fools!

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE
div.p: "LA DANNAZIONE DI FAUST."

"La Dannazione di Paust" was given again last night, in a performance which reflected the greatest oredit on management. The choran were again, for the most part, in excellent tone, and the stadenta sang their big Pague at the end of Act II. in most spirited. This was indeed a number which might well have been ignored rather than the somewhat sugary cereal flight of Silfide later on. Mefisto fole was once more excellent, and between Boito and Berlier he must experience no little difficulty in relapsing into the prose of lite above ground. But we cannot deny that, with all these merits, the piece shield is our opinion be played a Berlios wrote it, that is, me concerto for orchestra and chords. The music is so impressive and opening that given a full accompanying programac it is baid to see how soonary and eating brightens the impression. It is in the movie that we would like to rivet our attention. We do not oare to have it incidental, even to the greatest triumphs of stage management: for it comes, after Beito, overwhelming with its grent genius the work of that patient hack.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL CLUB DANCE.
div.p: The dance given last night by the members of the Khedivial Club was a very great success. Notwithstanding the bad weather that prevailed there were 400 guests present. It is needless to say that the olav's preemies looked their best, profusely decorated as they were with the choicest plants and brilliantly lit op with altitude of electrie lampe. By eleven o'clock the large reading room, which is used as a ball-room, was full, and doing bad began. The scene presented was charming in the extreme. The ladies were most bands only be owned, the light colours of their beautiful tulettes contracting with the dark green opi form of the 60tbR flash and the red costs of the Dublin Fusiliers, the officers of both their regiments being present in fall foron. It is quite impossible to give the names of thore present ; but we noticed H. B. the Governor of Alexandria, the officers of the Army of Occupation, the Consular Cerpe, judges, Government officials, and the elite of the English and foreign society.

A most excellent rapper, for which the elub is renowned, was served to over 10 guests, after which the cotillon began. Mrs. Rees and Miss Holland, assisted by Mr. Sidney Wilkio. son and Mr. Reer, led this dance, and it was due to their efforts that it proved huge Success. The presents given away were profese, and in some cases of a very rich nature. The greatest prison is due to the ladies we have mentioned, who took the atmoet pains and were indefatigable in their attentions to every great. Such was their agreement that the cotillion, which began at 1 o'clock, did not end until four a.m.
Before ending our report of this most successful dance, we must mention that all the members of the club did their best to entertain their guests, and were ably supported by their active secretary.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Duke of Connaught, in his forthcoming visit to Egypt and the East, will bring with him, besides his A.D.C., Mr. Myles Ponsonby. an old comrade of bie at Tel-el-Kebir, Major General Sir John Maxwell, K.C.B. Sir John SNS & subaltern in the First Battalion of the Black Watch then, and was taking, as wu the Deke, bis first tam of war service He was to see pleaty more, M A.D.C. to Grenfell at Ginis, where he got hie D.8.0; at Dongola, where he got bio brevet licet coloneloy ; sed at Omdar mar, where he commanded the Second Rp tine Brigade. The me South Africa, where he had the Fourteenth Brigade, and finished op - Military Governor of Pretoria.

The Duke'A.D.O., Mr. Myles Ponsonby, in the second son of that sometime baby City man, Lord Danomonon, who is now eighth Earl of Bessborough, and who married the youngest of the present Lord Wimborne'. Sve sister. Mr. Ponsonby, who is . lien tenant Grenadier Guards, but already had no experience A.D.C., with Sir H A. Blake, in Ceylon. The Duke and both bis others may be considered fairly non-proof.
Lady Lovin Magenis and Lady Lowry Corry, sisters of the Earl of Belmore, and Mine St. Aubyn and Mis Lowry Corry, arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Messagerie Maritime steamer.

Sir Robert Hamilton Lang K.CMD, director of the imperial Ottoman Bank and formerly British member of the Dairy Sapieha Administration, in arriving at Alexandria by the Messageries Maritimes stencer on Tuesday next. After the abort stay at Alexandria, I will proceed to Cairo and Upper Egypt.
M Sootidis, Hellenic Console-Gewerk yesterday presented to M. Zavedachi the insignia of the Order of the Saviour of Greece, conferred upon him by the King of the Hellenes.
Baron and Baroness Hans Phyffer,of Lucerne, are staying at the Savoy Hotel. Baron Pfyffer represents the Rite Company, who are erecting a large hotel at Karel Nil.

M. Pierre Loti, the celebrated French novelist, intends to spend part of the winter in Egypt. He embarks on board the Menang arios Maritimes 8.8. Sydney today at Marseille and is due to arrive at Port Said on the other inst.
Dr. Bloni Pasba has been appointed permanent member of the Legislative Council.

Mr. Douglas Morice, late sub-local director of the Alexandria Customs, is leaving for Cairo to-day in order to take a new post at the Finance Ministry. His official designation will be sub director of the Secretariat at the Ministry of Finance.
The salary of Mr. King Lewis, director general of Customs, has been increased to LE 1,206 per annum.
Mr. Wolle, the new director general of the Department of Agriculture and Technical Education, will draw a wiary of LB 1,750 per endum.
Lieut. Col. Hall, A.O.D, arrived at Cairo from Ceylon on Monday.
Rev. B E Smith, CP, bas been granted two months' leave of absence.
The passengers on the train de luxe on Monday for Upper Egypt were Mine Willmot, Mr. Maadisy, Mr. Wobh, Mme Bresser, Mr. Baer, Aly Bey, Dr. and Mr. Whitehead, Mr. and Mrs. Choolton.

A considerable number of entertainments are being given this year at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan, which is more or you're than ever, and the wise step has been taken of appointing an entertainment committee. The savoy dress ball, which has always been 0 nocessful in former years, bus been fixed this season for the 95th iost., on the following day there is to be gyokbans, and on the 28th ymateur theatricale are to be given.
